newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Plains feedlot cattle market inactive - trade.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Plains feedlot cattle market inactive - trade.

text.p: U.S. Plains feedlot cattle markets near midday were inactive, with no reported sales following active trading late Thursday, feedlot sources said.
Sales Thursday were mostly after 1500 CST at $66.00, steady with last week although USDA reported a few pens of steers and heifers sold at $66.25.
A few packer bids Friday at $65.00 per cwt were passed by owners who were generally asking $67.00, cattle feeders said.
Weekly sales in Kansas were pegged Thursday by USDA at 83,900 head, including 24,200 or about 29 percent previously contracted or formulated cattle.
Week-to-date sales in the Texas Panhandle and western Oklahoma area through Thursday at 62,400 head, including 17,100 formulated cattle, USDA said.

Most of this week's showlist in Kansas was sold while a few Panhandle-area feedyards were carrying supplies over into next week. However, most feedlots remained current in their marketings, sources said.
The currentness was expected to keep asking levels at $67.00 to $68.00 next week, several cattle feeders said. However, slipping beef prices could stymie bullish enthusiasm, they said.
